question: Reflecting on your earlier involvement with crowdsourced security at companies like PayPal and Magento, how do you see those experiences influencing your overall perspective on integrating security into product management?

inputs.question: Reflecting on your earlier involvement with crowdsourced security at companies like PayPal and Magento, how do you see those experiences influencing your overall perspective on integrating security into product management?

conversationHistory.content: Can you please share your background and your role at your current organization?

My current role is a Senior Manager of Product Management. My background is in engineering and product management with a focus on security. I spent several years working in security-related roles at Magento, an e-commerce company acquired by PayPal, eBay, and later by Adobe. At those companies, I worked directly on crowdsourced security. PayPal was one of the very first companies to have a public bug bounty program.

You mentioned working with crowdsourced security initiatives at companies like PayPal and Magento. Could you elaborate on how those early experiences have shaped your approach to product development and security management in your current role?
I would rather not answer this

questions: Could you share some general insights on how your early experiences with crowdsourced security initiatives might inform your approach to integrating security into product management today?
Reflecting on your time at PayPal and Magento, are there particular lessons from those crowdsourced security initiatives that you find relevant to your current role in product management?

To what extent have your experiences with crowdsourced security, possibly on a scale from 1 to 10, driven your strategy for incorporating security considerations into your product management processes?
